ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained better writing and analytical abilities through discussing and examining such diverse material. I gained so much knowledge on the memory works and testimony that is invaluable.

I learned so much about Algerian history and French imperialism in North and West Africa from the perspective of people experiencing France's colonial violence. Through our study of aesthetic objects and anarchives, I also learned that there are many valid forms of recording and embodying history beyond formal archives and texts.
This course addressed the lasting influence of colonialism on African literature and the many ways those impacts can be seen in other forms of media.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength of the course in the uniqueness of the material. Every week we got to explore new material and contexts. Also, Professor Jarvis cultivated such a welcoming and productive discussion environment.

Strengths: The readings and films were interesting and thought-provoking, the weekly reading response prompts helped me distill my thoughts into a concise format, our seminar discussions were very engaging (thanks to Professor Jarvis's and Walid's leadership and the grad students' presentations), and feedback on all of our assignments (even the weekly reading responses) was very thorough. I also appreciated that the midterm and final assignments afforded us lots of space for creativity.
Weaknesses: none!

As an undergraduate in a course split about half and half with grad students, I thought the format of this class was very conducive to meaningful conversation from a range of perspectives. I only wish we could have had a more complete round-table setup for discussion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! It doesn't matter where you are coming from in terms of major or background, this course will bring you powerful insights on the world around you. Professor Jarvis is one of my favorite professors of all time and you will leave the course having learned so much. Don't be intimidated by the subject or material. Come in with a willingness to learn and you will gain so much.

YES! Definitely! You will have super interesting discussions with your peers about the readings, feel very supported by the teaching team, engage with eye-opening texts and multimedia, and delve into important, often-overlooked questions about the very ways in which history is recorded and passed on.
Yes! whether you have taken comparative literature courses at Yale before or not, this course is accessible and Professor Jarvis is great.
